H0.text: The object's diameter is the information that will best help scientists determine whether an object is a comet, an asteroid, or a meteoroid.

H1.text: The object's composition is the information that best helps scientists determine whether an object is a comet, an asteroid, or a meteoroid.

H2.text: The shape of the object's orbit best helps scientists determine whether an object is a comet, an asteroid, or a meteoroid.

H3.text: The speed at which the object travels is the information that will best help scientists determine whether the object is a comet, an asteroid, or a meteoroid.

A4.text: Comets are often classified according to the length of their orbital periods: The longer the period the more elongated the ellipse.

A5.text: The finding is unexpected because comets, not asteroids, are typically considered to sprout jets and plumes.

A6.text: NEOWISE observed more than 100,000 asteroids of the main belt and determined rough sizes of the majority of observed objects.

A7.text: The light spectra, combined with trajectory and light curve measurements, have yielded various compositions and densities, ranging from fragile snowball-like objects with density about a quarter that of ice, to nickel-iron rich dense rocks.

A8.text: The fastest move at about 42 km/s through space in the vicinity of Earth's orbit.
